Award.AbstractNarration:
The recently demonstrated ability to stretch out long segments of DNA for genomic mapping points to a need to better understand the behavior of DNA in extreme confinement. This goal of this proposal is to develop an "engineering quality" description for the equilibrium properties and dynamics of long DNA molecules under extreme confinement in a nanochannel and to compare the predictions with experimental observations generated by BNG and its technology.

The success of this project can help the development of this new DNA mapping technology by providing a fundamental understanding of DNA confined in nanochannels. This is also an excellent academic-industrial partnership that can help the development of next-generation DNA sequencing and mapping technologies.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Genome mapping in nanochannels is an emerging method for creating scaffolds for de novo genome sequencing and detecting structural variations in genomes. The technology relies on stretching long DNA molecules in square nanochannels with a 45 nm cross section, which is similar to the length scale over which DNA will bend due to thermal energy. The theories for stretching DNA were developed in 1977 (for weak confinement) and 1983 (for strong confinement), but the channels used for genome mapping do not satisfy the assumptions in either of these limiting cases. In this GOALI project, the University of Minnesota and BioNano Genomics collaborated to develop a fundamental understanding of the physics of confining a DNA molecule in a 45 nm channel and test whether stronger confinement would improve the technology.

The key outcome of this research was the verification of Odijk’s theory for confinement of semiflexible polymers in channels near the persistence length. Using advanced simulation methods developed by the Minnesota team, they were able to confirm all of the key hypotheses of this theory for square, rectangular and circular nanochannels. In doing so, they refuted alternate theories for confined DNA. The Minnesota team also developed a complete description of the hydrodynamics of confined DNA over the full range of confinement, from very small channels to very wide ones, that plays a key role determining the relevant time scales for genome mapping experiments.

While the Odijk theory is valid under certain strong inequalities, these inequalities are only weakly satisfied for DNA. As a result, the Minnesota team and BioNano Genomics worked together to determine to what extent Odijk’s theory (and the simulation model developed at Minnesota) describes genome mapping technology as used in practice. Taking advantage of the high-throughput experimental setup available at BioNano Genomics, this collaboration revealed a skew-left dependence to the DNA stretching. These data provide a strong test for any future theories of DNA stretching in nanochannels.

In addition to understanding the stretching of DNA when it is confined in a small channel, the Minnesota team also developed simulation models for the stretching of DNA by an external force in the absence of confinement and when the DNA is confined between parallel plates. In the absence of confinement, these simulations provided a new interpolation formula for the stretching that accounts for DNA-DNA interactions under weak forces. In slit confinement, the Minnesota team showed that these interactions lead to a number of different types of stretching behavior, including novel modes that have since been confirmed experimentally by others.

The results obtained in this project have important implications for the practice of genome mapping. The theoretical results provide a basic engineering framework for the further enhancement of the technology and explanations for why the existing technology works.  The experimental work provides useful data for improving the operation of genome mapping, since the probability of observing different extents of stretching can be used to improve the statistical models for constructing genome maps.

This research project provided training for 2 postdoctoral researchers, 4 graduate students, and 2 undergraduate students, which includes two female graduate students. The results of this project were reported in 11 peer-reviewed manuscripts and formed the subject of presentations at national meetings and invited seminars.
